content.webTitle: Frankie Dettori and Victoria Pendleton join the new ITV racing team

fields.headline: Frankie Dettori and Victoria Pendleton join the new ITV racing team
fields.bodyText: Frankie Dettori and Victoria Pendleton are among the new names revealed to have joined ITV’s racing team in the build-up to the channel’s return to the sport in January. ITV will take over from Channel 4, having won a four-year exclusive contract, and details of its presenting team have been leaking out in recent weeks but the station has now opted to clarify some of the remaining details in a press release. Dettori, now 45 and beginning to consider a life after the saddle, has won some praise for contributions on Channel 4 over the past two years. ITV say he will be “a regular contributor … working around his riding commitments”. Pendleton, meanwhile, “will bring her perspective” to the coverage. An Olympic champion cyclist, she pulled off one of the more remarkable sporting feats of recent years when finishing fifth in a steeplechase at the Cheltenham Festival, barely a year after sitting on a horse for the first time. But there is no mention of Sir Anthony McCoy, an insightful contributor on Channel 4 since ending a career of unprecedented success as a jump jockey in 2015. McCoy indicated in August that he did not expect to be part of ITV’s final team. “They seem to have announced their presenters and I wish them the best of luck and hope they do well,” he told The Guardian at that time. Oli Bell is to present ITV’s version of the Morning Line, a Saturday preview show, while Richard Hoiles and Mark Johnson have now been confirmed as its commentators. In addition to other names already known, Brough Scott is to be a regular guest on ITV Racing, while the channel’s weather forecaster Lucy Verasamy will provide reports with a specific focus on future racing events. Niall Sloane, ITV’s director of sport, said: “We believe this line-up, which draws on a range of people from within racing and beyond, will enrich our coverage with the quality, expertise, insight and personality to bring home to viewers the full enjoyment and appreciation of this wonderful sport.” My Tent Or Yours, who was second in the Champion Hurdle in March after an absence of almost two years, missed his planned return to action at Kempton on Sundaybecause the ground was judged to lack sufficient give. His trainer, Nicky Henderson, won the race anyway with Hargam, who also carries the colours of JP McManus. “Last year, we were plagued with sore shins so he never got to run until the Champion Hurdle,” Henderson said. “When you’re at his age and had his sort of setbacks, we can’t afford another one. “I got cold feet at the end of the day. It’s a long time until March and at his age we can’t get it wrong again. That would be the end of his career. It would be all over. “I think we have to look at Haydock or the Fighting Fifth [in November], maybe come back here for the Christmas Hurdle.”
